nodes.bodyText: we should expand this where clause to pull records based on create_time also as after sometime CANCELLED query list will expand. Something like create_time after current-date minus maxRunTimeSeconds;
Also the FilterExpression should be the method argument as elide will be controlling the Filter, where as users can provide their implementation of getActiveAsyncQueryCollection method.
throw the exception as IllegalStateException.
we should update the getRunningTransactions method to get this and we can remove the getter method on TransactionMap as its not used anyplace else.
we can combine these two if statements with an OR

a couple of things we can probably do to improve the performance here:
i) When the match occurs in if clause, after processing the if block we should break the inner loop
ii) we should remove the object from asyncQueryCollection when a match happens so that the size keeps reducing as the transaction loop move on.
i think getAsyncQueryCancelIntervalSeconds sounds better as Delay could be taken as differently.
queryCancellationIntervalSeconds

nodes.bodyText: plz remove commented code
please include a test case in DefaultAsyncQueryDAOTest.java for this method.

I'm not sure this is correct.  This filter will look for any query that is canceled, queued, or processing that is more recent than now minus max runtime.  Later, we filter this collection by queries that are canceled or having ran longer than max runtime.
I think there are two problems:

I don't believe the second condition will ever evaluate.  Those queries have already been removed by the DAO filter.
I think it is possible to miss queries that are canceled but have run longer (for whatever reason) than  the max runtime.
The interface contract for the AsyncQueryDAO would be cleaner if the filterExpression for this method and others was an actual FilterExpression object instead of a String.
Should we change this to UUID.fromString(id)?

I wonder if this would read better with a more descriptive name (although longer):
getAsyncQueryCancelCheckIntervalSeconds
Maybe a better approach is to move all of the async query settings into a struct of some kind to namespace them (so they aren't so long)
we can take care of this in the download pr
I think the definition of this is vague.  What is this interval for?  Let's get a more descriptive name and a better description of its intended use.

nodes.bodyText: This is too broad and is swallowing exceptions that need to be propagated.
The DAO should not swallow exceptions.  Utilities need to propagate exceptions and let the calling code handle them (or the utility will have limited reuse and can only be used in limited contexts).

Relying on time to find the queries that need to be canceled has some race conditions and other issues with configuration that can cause problems.
Instead of filtering on time, I think we need to introduce another state - CANCEL_COMPLETE or something along those lines that marks which queries have been successfully canceled.
It will be more efficient to call asyncQueryDao.updateAsyncQueryCollection which can do a bulk update

Shouldn't this calculation be:
NOW - query.getCreatedOn().getTime() > maxRunTimeSeconds
So two changes - createdOn instead of updatedOn and invert the subtraction  operands (we can keep the absolute value though).
Another thing (I'm probably going back on prior comments here), but I think tx.cancel can throw an exception.  If this thread is terminated by an exception, will the executor schedule another?

We probably want to invert the order of canceling the transaction and marking the status to complete.  If canceling throws an exception, it will leave a query in the canceling state with nothing to clean it up.

The way the code is now, cancellation happens before we mark the status of the query as CANCEL_COMPLETE. So if there were to be an exception, the query status will not change, so it can be picked up for cancellation in the next run of the cancel thread...
I was testing the code in example application and discovered that the executor does not schedule another thread if it encounters an exception. Can I catch exceptions, log them?

The DAO will be more usable if we don't tie down the contract with constraints like limiting the status to QUEUED, PROCESSING, etc.
This can just be a load method that takes a filter expression.  Let the calling code determine what states or other bits to filter on.

nodes.bodyText: Change the name to reflect this is a simple loadQueries or something.

I feel like these tests don't test too much of the code that was added.
We have all this set interaction between running transactions and transactions that exist in the database.  We ought to be testing (with unit tests):

Async queries in the database that are COMPLETE, CANCEL_COMPLETE are skipped.
Only the async queries that reflect running queries in the transaction registry are canceled.
Queries that exceed their runtime are canceled (but only if they are in the transaction registry).
Queries that didn't exceed their runtime are not canceled.

That's not an exhaustive test - but that will verify the functionality works as we expect.

Similar to my above comment - stronger tests would have a list of mock queries with different conditions of staleness - and we verify that:

the ones we expect to be canceled are canceled
the ones that we expect to be deleted are deleted
the ones we expect to be ignored are ignored.
This variable is not used any more, can be removed.
may be we should store transactionRegistry.getRunningTransaction(uuid) in a variable and check for null before calling cancel.
maxRunTimeMinutes is not needed any more
Any reason not to make this public?

Verify the status.
It's possible for this test to fail because of a 1ms gap between when this date is calculated and when the delete filter is generated.   We'll need to find a less brittle approach.
Same comment on date.

The other comment for standalone was:
"Number of seconds between async query cancellation checks."
Let's use the same comment for both standalone and spring and maybe change to:
"Polling interval to identify async queries that should be canceled."
Also, 300 seconds is way too long for this interval.  It should probably be somewhere in the 1-10 second range by default.
